PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1  As no feasibility study is available, this consulting service will prepare the West Bengal 
North South Corridor Project for possible financing by ADB. A feasibility study with engineering 
design for all project components and economic and financial assessment will be carried out. 
The main outcome of the technical assistance (TA) will be the project design fully agreed to by 
the Government and ADB and related safeguards planning documents prepared.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

will be financed by ADB, on a grant basis, from funds provided by the Government of the United 
Kingdom through DFID under the TA Cluster 0003-IND: Advanced Project Preparedness for 
Poverty Reduction.  The Government will provide counterpart support in the form of office 
accommodation, remuneration and per diem of counterpart staff and contingencies.

D.  Consulting Services 
4  The State of West Bengal is on the threshold of a new era of industrialization. One of the 
major  infrastructural  requirements  of  industry  is  proper  road  connectivity.  In  this  regard, 
connectivity  with  Haldia  port  is  of  paramount  importance.  The  existing  road  is  of  2-lane 
standard. Geographically, this road section passes through the centroidal axis of West Bengal. 
The districts situated along this alignment are Purba Medinipur, Paschim Medinipur, Hooghly, 
Bardhaman, Birbhum and Murshidabad. Therefore, the development of this alignment would 
maximize the effect of infrastructural development, economic growth and poverty reduction in 
this area. This route, if developed to 4-lane standard, would enhance the transport to various 
market  places  of  local  agricultural  products  like  rice,  potato,  sesame,  jute  etc.,  which  are 
produced in abundance in Hooghly, Bardhaman, Murshidabad, etc. 
 
5  ADB's project preparatory technical assistance will assist the Public Works (Roads) 
Government of West Bengal (GoWB) to undertake the following studies: 
 
a.  Feasibility of the Proposed Project. The TA will establish the technical, environmental, 
social, economical, and financial viability of the project and prepare detailed project reports for 
rehabilitation and upgrading of the existing road to 2-lane with paved shoulders and / or 4 lane 
divided carriageway configuration depending on the traffic levels, provision of new alignment, if 
required for better connectivity of the corridor and / or provision of bypasses. Traffic surveys, 
origin-destination surveys, pavement condition surveys and axle load surveys will be carried out 
for this purpose.  
 
b.  Detailed Engineering Design of the Proposed Project.  The TA will carry out the 
detailed  engineering  design  of  the  project  including  detailed  highway  design,  design  of 
pavement and overlay with options for flexible or rigid pavements, design of bridges and cross 
drainage  structures  and  grade  separated  structures,  design  of  service  roads, quantities of 
various  items,  detailed  working  drawings,  detailed  cost  estimates,  economic  and  financial 
viability analyses, environmental and social feasibility, social and environmental action plans as 
appropriate  and  documents  required  for  tendering  the  project  on  commercial  basis  for 
international competitive bidding. This will entail, among other activities, detailed topographic 
surveys,  pavement  investigations,  sub-grade  characteristics  and  strength:  investigation  of 
required sub-grade and subsoil characteristics and strength for road and embankment design 
and sub soil investigation; and hydraulic investigation for bridge design. 
 
c.  Preparation  of  Safeguard  Documents.  The  TA  will  prepare  initial  environmental 
examination/  environmental  Impact  Assessment  Report  (as  appropriate)  including 
Environmental Management Plan (EMP), Resettlement Plan & Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) 
and indigenous peoples’ safeguard documents (if required) conforming to the Guidelines of the 
Government of India, State Government and Asian Development Bank as appropriate for each

construction package section. Appropriate social and environmental surveys will be carried out 
for this purpose.  
 
d.  Efficiency Assessment of Intermodal Connectivity. The TA will assess intermodal 
efficiency, including port operations and port road usage; and recommend measures to resolve 
inefficiencies including development of a risk assessment-based overloading control mechanism 
using IT tools, which will allow the road and enforcement authorities to control overloading by 
more precise targeting of suspect vehicles thus ensuring that port clearance times for vehicle 
traffic is not affected while at the same time asset sustainability is ensured. Detailed surveys of 
commodities/consigners/consignees at Haldia Port together with discussion with port, customs, 
and enforcement authorities will be necessary to develop this mechanism to improve efficiency 
in the port and port roads.  
 
e.  Institutional Assessment of PWRD.  The TA will assess the institutional capacity of 
PWRD to carry out planning and programming of the state roads sector and recommend 
improvements in systems, databases and procedures that are necessary to enable the PWRD 
to function as a modern road sector agency. The institutional assessment will also look into the 
maintenance codes of practice and training needs that are necessary for this purpose.

6  The outline terms of references (TOR) for the project preparatory TA consultants are 
described in paras. 7 to 8. The detailed TOR is attached as Supplementary Appendix. 
 
7  The activities required under the consulting services include but are not limited to the 
following major tasks. 
(i)  Environmental and social impact assessment, including those related to cultural 
properties, natural habitats, involuntary resettlement etc; and from the gender 
perspective for identifying mechanisms to ensure women’s and girl’s participation 
in the project including a gender action plan if needed. 
(ii)  Public consultation, including consultation with  communities located along the 
road, NGOs working in the area, other stakeholders and relevant Government 
departments at all the different stages of assignment (such as inception stage, 
feasibility stage, and once final designs are concretized).

Appendix 4  13 
 
(iii)  Detailed  reconnaissance,  and  identification  of  possible  improvements  in  the 
existing  alignment  and  bypassing  congested  locations  with  alternatives,  and 
evaluation of different alternatives; 
(iv)  Traffic  studies  including  traffic  surveys  and  axle  load  survey  and  demand 
forecasting for the next thirty years, including analysis of non-motorized transport 
and subregional traffic; 
(v)  Inventory and condition surveys for road, bridges, cross-drainage structures and 
drainage provisions; 
(vi)  Detailed topographic surveys using Total Stations and GPS; 
(vii)  Pavement  investigations,  including  sub-grade  characteristics  and  strength: 
investigation of required sub-grade and subsoil characteristics and strength for 
road and embankment design and sub soil investigation; 
(viii)  Identification of sources of construction materials; 
(ix)  Detailed  design  of  road,  its  x-sections,  horizontal  and  vertical  alignment  and 
design of embankment of height more than 6m and also in poor soil conditions 
and where density consideration require, even lesser height embankment.  
(x)  Identification of the type and the design of intersections; 
(xi)  Design of complete drainage system and disposal point for storm water 
(xii)  Value analysis / value engineering and project costing; 
(xiii)  Economic analysis, including consideration of subregional impacts in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects and Handbook for 
the Economic Analysis of Subregional Projects; and financial analyses; 
(xiv)  Contract packaging and implementation schedule. 
(xv)  Strip plan indicating the scheme for carriageway widening, location of all existing 
utility services (both over- and underground) and the scheme for their relocation, 
trees  to  be  felled  and  planted  and  land  acquisition  requirements  including 
schedule for LA: reports documents and drawings arrangement of estimates for 
cutting of trees and shifting of utilities from the concerned department; 
(xvi)  Preparation of detailed project report, cost estimate, approved for construction 
drawings, rate analysis, detailed bill of quantities, bid documents for execution of 
civil works through budgeting resources. 
(xvii)  Design of toll plaza and identification of their numbers including working drawings 
(xviii) Design of weighing stations, parking areas and rest areas. 
(xix)  Any other user oriented facility enroute toll facility. 
(xx)  Tie-in of on-going/sanctioned works of MORT&H/ NHAI/ other agencies. 
(xxi)  Preparation of social plans for the project affected people as per policy of the 
Asian Development Bank. 
(xxii)  Carrying out institutional assessment of the PWRD and recommending pragmatic 
improvements 
(xxiii) Preparing  training  material  to  ensure  that  modern  maintenance  practices  are 
imparted to all relevant PWRD personnel 
(xxiv) Preparing efficiency improvement measures of the port and port roads, including 
overloading  control  measures  that  use  a  risk  assessment-based  approach  to 
target vehicles most at risk of being overloaded during egress/ingress into the port 
based  on  prior  review  of  relevant  cargo  clearance  documentation  filed  with 
Customs and port authorities.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
9  The Department of Economic Affairs of the Government will be the Executing Agency for 
the subproject. The Public Works (Roads) Department, Government of West Bengal will be the 
implementing agency. 
 
10  The PPTA will be implemented over 8 months, beginning in 19 March 2012 and ending 
in 19 November 2012. An appropriate international consultant firm that can supply a team with 
expertise in the areas of feasibility studies, detailed engineering and institutional assessment of 
road sector agencies will be recruited for the TA. National consultants in these fields will be 
engaged  by  the  international  consultant  firm,  which  will  have  overall  responsibility  for  the 
consulting services. It is anticipated that a total of 8 person-months international and 55 person-
months national consulting services will be required. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  The  consultant  firm  will  be  selected  according  to  quality-  and  cost-based  selection 
(QCBS)  procedures  and  full  technical  proposal  will  be  requested  from  short-listed  firms. 
Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time).
